data.text: Clipless: Is a Spare Pair of Cleats Necessary when Bikepacking?

No, they will last longer than all your shoes

If a clip breaks or something (which is incredibly rare), you can just flip over the pedals and ride while pedaling the flat side until you get to a town where you can buy replacement clips or pedals.

data.text: SPD pedals are about the most reliable things on a bike. They are also way, more functional than straps. Been there done that, will never go back. Good cycling shoes can be just fine for walking in and far better for riding with. I've hiked up a volcano and through the jungle in my walking shoes as well used them as all day shoes. Straps limit shoe choice far more.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: I bet if you gave spd a chance you would love it....you can always carry a pair of crocks or sandals for off the bike. Come on Eric, try it! üòâ

data.text: That happened to me when I fell off and my bike got stuck on top of me with my bags lol. You can lower the tension to make it easier to unclip...that's what I did.

data.text: yeah, if we'd be back in the early 1990s. Clipped is and always has been a suboptimal solution, leading to the invention of clipless. And no, back in the days we weren't happy with clips. Falling with those shitty things was a guarantee for injuries.

I find them hugely effective and when I ride flats It feels like I have so much less power/am running on empty and hills are so much harder. Plus you can use alternate different muscles groups to give the others a rest.

data.text: - sounds like you didn't know what you were doing and didn't practice to develop the new reflex. Far harder to get out of straps than clipless pedals.

data.text: post some studies. Here's mine; Pedaling Technique of Elite Endurance Cyclists: Changes With Increasing Workload at Constant Cadence was published in the International Journal of Sport Biometrics 7:29-53, 1991. However, it seems to come to the conclusion that they don't really make any difference as far as pedaling efficiency goes.

Clipless Pedals Vs Flat Pedals - Which Is Faster? | GCN Does Science

data.author: Brett Jensen

data.text: and, this is a bikepacking page. The debate Might be more revelant on a racing page. But please post some of your "good science" studies. Please.
data.author: Brett Jensen

data.text: - Several obvious problems there before I even dig deeper on that first one. Firstly - Only 14 subjects! Secondly they are only measuring output, not efficiency. Using more muscles to output 250W or whatever is more efficient than using fewer muscles. Two very different things. On alog day's riding this really matters. Thirdly - had the subjects actually learnt to pedal correctly? It takes time and considered practice to relearn how to pedal with clips/clipless compared to flats. You also have to build up the alternate muscle groups being used. I can pedal with almost zero foot pressure through ball of foot, where the traditional effort is being done and still out sprint other folk, because I can pull up so effectively due to a LOT of good practice. Despite 'studies' showing this is supposedly not possible. Fourthly, a 40km time trial with a high cadence is not representative of all cycling. But crucially of all this study has not about actually about using clipless or flat pedals. It's to do with pedal orientation and ankling technique and everyone was either clipped or using clipless. Dear me! If using flats instead of clipless, then your saddle height and foot on pedals is also changed, which then alters angle of foot, so you use a slightly different biomechanical action. You need to compare those two different ways of pedalling properly to draw valid conclusions. That was not done here.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: trying to say this should not be on this page because it's bikepacking is pretty dumb, because efficient pedalling is VERY germane to bikepacking. You are also not the arbiter of what is relevant on this page. I can't post studies saying how effective clipless is because as I already stated every study I have seen on subject has been risible usually for same reasons that I mention above. The fact you post GCN Youtube stuff and think it's real science, shows how little you know about actual science. Funny how that nonsense is the only one you actually linked. Can't find the second study via google that compares flats Vs clipless. But then you thought the first did that when it did not. So no surprises there.

data.text: Ok buddy. Happy trails. Lol

And then generally prefered clipless. Not saying it was a good science testing, but it countered your claims regardless. So no idea why you thought it would.

Ride what you want, just don't spread fact free nonsense here. There's a low tolerance for that here.

data.author: Brett Jensen

data.text: Dear me , scraping the barrel now for opinion pieces that talk about the 'clipless mafia', make spurious claims and similar proves nothing. All you are doing is demonstrating you don't understand science and struggle with basic literacy when you earlier you post 'proofs' that had nothing to do with or contradicted your claims. I have a background in teaching and analysing body movement as it happens and am very nerdy about efficiency. So whilst riding today I thought I'd do a simple experiment. So I used just one foot to keep pedalling up a steep slope either using upwards pull on cleats or just pushing down unclipped. Clipped in it was easy to keep going, unclipped, it was near impossible without other leg to provide the downforce and keep pedal turning past dead spot. Now obviously we use both feet to pedal, but I had more effective/usable power and most importantly the load was split between more muscle groups. Using four lots of muscles to output say 200w is better than using two lots of muscles, particularly when during endurance riding and it'll reduce lactic acid build up when doing sprints. And we haven't even talked about the benefits of clipless when riding techy/bumpy terrain.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: where's YOUR links? Huh? What ya got? You keep mentioning science, so where is it? It's just Your secret science? Share that secret sauce! C'mon dude, what ya got? All the opinions and studies I find are crap you say, so bring on the real science, I really want to see it. So far, NOTHING! Well except for your personal experiment that is certainly not scientific in the least. LMFAO. Well you did personally attact me, my literacy. I guess that's all you got. STILL WAITING.

data.text: As I stated up front, I've never seen any claim on this subject that was not problematic in its methodology . Not that I've seen any actual serious studies on it at all. You also comprehensively failed to link to any, which only underscores *my* point and not yours. The fact that no-one races flats on road and vanishingly few do off road, only indicates flats are not better. Because racing by its very nature tends to winnow out slower tech.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: On any remote ride trip of more than a few days and away from a good bike shop i carry one spare one, as light, small and easy to carry. That said they are super strong so be surprised if you need. More likely if screws come out and if flicks off and can‚Äôt find - but you would be pretty unlucky!. But ALWAYS take spare screws. Best way to ruin an adventure and get knee issues if one comes out mid trip.

data.text: Shimano SPD pedals are almost indestructible and tend to outlast bikes. Their cleats usually outlast shoes too. Make sure bolts are tight. Because that's about the only likely problem. Use good quality Allen keys, because crappy ones may not fit as well and round out bolts as you tighten them.

data.text: Anyone on here saying things like "I've had the same cleats for years" does not actually ride. Cleats are purposely made of softer metal than the pedal, so cleats wear out. I ride ~200mi per week and change my cleats monthly. I have an extra cleat set in my bike kit along with tube etc.
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: Monthly? Wow that‚Äôs a lot of cleat changes. I mean, I probably change mine once per year, with respect to the OP‚Äôs question, but it seems carrying an extra set of cleats on a bikepacking trip seems, to me, extraneous.

data.text: Send me your "worn" ones--unless you are dragging your feet on the asphalt for half those miles, there is no way you are wearing out a set of cleats in 1000-ish miles.

data.text: I have extra clear bolts in my kit. Not extra cleats.
data.author: Greg Russell

data.text: I've averaged 50-100 miles per week(mostly on a mountain bike) quite regularly for the last decade. A lot of those miles include plenty of hike-a-bike, trail building and other general "hard on cleat" activities. Not once have I ever worn out or had to replace a set of cleats, and some have been recycled to new shoes on more than one occasion... take that for what it's worth. I have had them come loose, however. Make sure you put a little dab of Loctite on the mounting screw threads.
data.author: Jeff Clemons

data.text: Cleats do NOT last forever. They do wear out. They wear out slowly though and you can feel the change slowly progressing. This gives you a heads up and plenty of time to find replacements. I don't pack extra cleats but it is a good idea to bring a couple extra bolts.
data.author: Corby Cobb

data.text: - they typically outlast shoes they are fitted to though. Currently wearing my winter/heavy duty boots that are possibly ten years old [I bought a replacement pair 3+ years back and still not used them] and they have been hammered. Never replaced the cleats. Most shoes don't last that long.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: Always bring an extra!

data.text: No

data.text: On the divide I bring an extra cleat and 4 screws. I double check every couple days to see it the screws are loosening.

data.text: I had one come loose, fall off 20 miles out. It was a lopsided ride home. I keep an extra one with my spare derailer hanger and spare bolts for my saddle.

data.text: Another reason to get pedals that have flats on one side and spd on the other.

If they come loose, which happens from time to time, most of the times you will notice it in time. I do more than 10.000km/year and a lot of hiking on my bike shoes. I have 2 pairs, so you can devide the infinity by half üòú
